titleInfo.title: MAP of the most INHABITED part of VIRGINIA containing the whole PROVINCE of MARYLAND with Part of PENSILVANIA, NEW JERSEY AND NORTH CAROLINA

mods.abstract: This is the first map to accurately depict the Blue Ridge Mountains and the first to lay down the colonial road system of Virginia. A great number of plantations are located and include the family names of the Virginia plantation owners of the period. The cartouche, showing a tobacco warehouse and wharf, is one of the earliest printed images of the Virginia tobacco trade. The original survey was conducted in 1750 and published in 1751. It was updated in 1755 to incorporate information from the journals of John Dalrymple and Christopher Gist.

physicalDescription.note: There is debate in the reference literature as to which state of the map this is; some reference literature doesn't discuss the 1775 edition of the Jefferys' American Atlas. What is certain is that Jefferys' atlas was published both in 1775 and 1776 and our copy appears to be from the 1776 edition. According to Phillips (1165 & 1166), the 1775 edition has "Joshua Fry & Peter Jefferson, 1775" and the 1776 edition has "Joshua Fry & Peter Jefferson in 1775".

mods.note: Both London and Currituk Inlet are given as meridians. This is the only map we've come across with such an obscure place for a meridian. State borders between Virginia and North Carolina are outlined in color.
